tossups.question: In inertial confinement fusion, a theoretical hole in a hohlraum would accurately model this phenomenon. Bose-Einstein statistics were first developed in order to resolve a problem explaining this phenomenon. The constant 2.9 times 10 to the negative -3 meters Kelvin is used to find the peak wavelength of this phenomenon in Wien's displacement law. The spectral distribution of this phenomenon as a function of temperature is given by (*) Planck's law. The power of this phenomenon is proportional to surface area times temperature to the 4th power, according to the Stefan-Boltzmann law. For 10 points, name this form of radiation emitted by objects that absorb all incident electromagnetic waves.
tossups.answer: blackbody radiation [accept blackbody after "radiation" is read; prompt on radiation by asking "from what kind of source?"]
tossups.answer_formatted: blackbody radiation [accept blackbody after "radiation" is read; prompt on radiation by asking "from what kind of source?]
promptable: radiation by asking "from what kind of source?

tossups.question: In one story by this man, Margot's schoolmates lock her in a closet, leading her to not experience the title phenomenon that happens once every 7 years. In addition to "All Summer in a Day," this author wrote a work in which the psychologist David suggests that the HappyLife Home be shut down. Another story by this author includes silhouettes of daily life such as depictions of two people doing yard work and two children playing a game of ball. That story is based around a (*) computer-run house that still functions after a nuclear fallout. This author wrote another short story in which George and Lydia are eaten by lions after their children lock them in the "nursery." For 10 points, name this American author of "There will come Soft Rains" and "The Veldt."

This leader's unseating was compared to "firing the Prime Minister for a traffic ticket" after being accused of election fraud by Raj Narain. During one campaign, this leader adapted an opponent's "remove her" slogan to a slogan translating to "Remove Poverty," Garibi Hatao. The Shah commission investigated forced sterilizations this leader conducted during a 21-month period known as the (*) Emergency. The Smiling Buddha nuclear tests were conducted by this leader. This leader ordered the invasion of the Golden Temple during Operation Blue Star, which led to her assassination by her own Sikh bodyguards. For 10 points, name this first female Prime Minister of India.

This religion believes that a savior figure will be born from a maiden who enters Lake Kansava. This religion believes that substances contaminated with nasu should touch neither the earth nor fire. In this religion, both the living and the dead will be required to walk through a river that feels like warm milk for righteous people during Frashokereti, when the Saoshyant will also come. This religion believes that two four-eyed dogs guard the (*) Chinvat bridge. This religion places dead bodies on dakhma, or towers of silence, where they are eaten by birds. The central text of this religion is the Avesta, which tells the story of the eternal conflict between Ahura Mazda and Angra Mainyu. For 10 points, name this dualistic Persian religion.
tossups.answer: Zoroastrianism [or Zarathustrism or Mazdayasna or Magianism; accept Mazdaism before "Mazda"]

tossups.question: Two components of the change in this quantity formed a pattern called the "Russian Cross" when measured in many former Warsaw Pact countries. Hans Rosling created the documentary Don't Panic in order to explain his views about why changes in this quantity are not that concerning. This quantity is multiplied by affluence and technology to give the impact on the environment. This quantity slightly declines in the fifth stage of the (*) demographic transition model. The exponential increase in this quantity can lead to famines in a Malthusian trap. It's not age, but this quantity's "pyramid" is somewhat inverted for Japan. Demographers study this quantity. For 10 points, name this quantity that is roughly equal to 7.7 billion people.
tossups.answer: human population [or number of people; accept clear equivalents]

tossups.question: This artist created a landscape work featuring three figures wearing red, blue, and green, symbolizing love, faith, and hope respectively. Gottlieb Christian Kuhn designed five baby angels and the eye of God for the frame of one artwork by this artist depicting a Cross in the Mountains. In addition to Chalk Cliffs on Rügen and the Tetschen Altar, this artist painted himself as an old man with a fur coat in an allegorical painting depicting (*) five boats of varying distances. This artist of The Stages of Life portrayed the shipwreck of the HMS Griper in The Sea of Ice and painted a man with a walking stick standing on a precipice before a cloud-covered landscape. For 10 points, name this German Romantic painter of Wanderer Above the Sea of Fog.

One type of these objects' death line is displayed on P-P-dot diagrams. Changes in rotational frequency cause glitches in these objects. These objects are found in a system that emanates gravitational waves, the Hulse-Taylor binary. The maximum mass of nonrotating types of these objects is approximately 2.2 solar masses, according to the (*) TOV limit. One type of these objects rotate more than 700 times per second in their millisecond variety. The lighthouse model explains how one type of these stars, pulsars, emit radiation from their poles. These stars are more dense than white dwarfs and are the result of a core-collapse supernova. For 10 points, name these stars that are composed of uncharged particles.
tossups.answer: neutron stars [accept millisecond pulsars before "pulsar"; accept neutron after "star" is read]
tossups.answer_formatted: neutron stars [accept millisecond pulsars before "pulsar; accept neutron after "star" is read]

tossups.question: A novel by this author contains a metaphor comparing the author's country to a speeding sled called a troika. The protagonist of that novel by this author is believed to be either Napoleon or Captain Kopeikin. The title character of a story by this author is caught with a forged passport while riding to Riga. That story by this author opens with the barber (*) Ivan finding the title object in his bread. One novel by this author sees Chichikov bargain for the titular Dead Souls, while another sees the title body part travel around St. Petersburg after detaching from Major Kovalyov's face. For 10 points, name this Russian author of "The Nose."

A group led by Cadex Herrera created a work that depicts this man seated in front of a sunflower on a blue background. Stanley Watts designed a seven hundred pound bronze statue depicting this man sitting on a bench. Chris Carnabuci designed a statue depicting this man inscribed with a caption describing how (*) "knees should be used to pray." Those statues were vandalized by a group promoting "LIFE, LIBERTY AND VICTORY," the Patriot Front. A statue dedicated to this man depicting a bronze fist was recently added to a square named after him in Minneapolis. For 10 points, name this man who was memorialized in murals after he was killed by Derek Chauvin.

In the leadup to one battle, this country performed a series of parachute operations known as Operation Castor. After failing to carry out orders issued by Christian de Castries, a soldier from this country named Charles Piroth committed suicide by hand grenade. Outposts of this country named Beatrice and Gabrielle were the target of a battle compared to a "rice bowl" by one side's leader. Vo (*) Nguyen Giap defeated this country's forces at the Battle of Dien Bien Phu. One of this country's colonies was split along the 17th parallel after this country's Fourth republic lost the First Indochina War. For 10 points, name this colonial power that fought against its former territories of Laos and Vietnam.

A poem by this author personifies "Great Time" who "sits enamored at your feet" and begins "amidst the rush and roar of life." The speaker of another poem by this author asks "oh to what foreign land do you sail" and requests that person to "take away my golden paddy." The thirty-fifth poem of a collection by this author describes a place "where words come out from the depth of truth" which ends by describing a (*) "heaven of freedom" and commands "my Father, let my country awake." That collection by this author had a prologue written by W.B. Yeats and opens with the line "thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure." For 10 points, name this Bengali poet of Gitanjali.

In one story, Kiyohime turns into one of these creatures and kills a Buddhist monk after he rejects her. The legendary sword Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi, one of the three imperial Regalia, was pulled from the tail of one of these creatures. The kami of the sea, Ryujin, is depicted as one of these creatures, leading to these creatures being associated with (*) rain prayers. Susano'o legendarily killed one of these creatures by using 8 vats of sake; that one of these creatures had 8 heads and 8 tails and was called Orochi. For 10 points, name these serpent-like mythological creatures that do not have wings nor breathe fire like their Western counterparts.
tossups.answer: dragon [accept serpent or snake before mention]

tossups.question: During a satellite conflict of this war, French troops massacred residents of a British frontier town in the Raid on Deerfield. A treaty allowing for the exchange of "English cloth" and "Portuguese wine" was negotiated by John Methuen during this war. The British were granted a monopoly on slave trade to one country following this war, the asiento. A palace in Oxfordshire is named after a battle in this war where the Duke of (*) Marlborough prevented the capture of Vienna, the Battle of Blenheim. The American theater of this conflict is known as Queen Anne's war. The Treaty of Utrecht ended this war. For 10 points, name this war where Louis XIV contested Philip V's ascension to the throne of an Iberian nation.
tossups.answer: War of the Spanish Succession [prompt on Queen Anne's war before mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: War of the Spanish Succession [prompt on Queen Anne's war before mentioned]

tossups.question: This quantity of a system equals the sum of the chemical potential times surface excess of each component in the Gibbs isotherm equation. This quantity for a pure liquid has an approximately linear relationship with temperature, according to the Eötvös rule. This quantity equals the increase in Gibbs free energy per increase in surface area at constant pressure and temperature. This quantity is traditionally measured in (*) dynes per centimeter. Adding a surfactant decreases this quantity. High values of this quantity allow some insects to walk across lakes. For 10 points, name this quantity that describes the cohesive forces between molecules on a liquid's surface.

This opera's overture begins with the cellos playing an eighth note A up to a long F followed by an eighth note E and a long D-sharp. A chord pioneered by this opera consists of F, B, D#, and G#. In this opera, Kurwenal reminds one character about the death of Morold. This opera ends with the aria "Mild und Leise," which is also known as the (*) Liebestod; the singer of that aria in this opera is promised in marriage to King Marke of Cornwall. In this opera's first act, the servant Brangane gives the title couple what she believes to be poison, but actually turns out to be a love potion. For 10 points, name this Wagner opera about the two title lovers.
tossups.answer: Tristan und Isolde [accept Tristan and Isolde]

tossups.question: The SOCAR towers in this country's capital is composed of two towers of different heights that curve around each other as they rise; that capital of this country is the largest city below sea level. This country's national language uses an upside-down letter e to represent the sound /æ/ ["a" in that]. This country contains the autonomous exclave of Nakhchivan. The Flame Towers are in this country's capital, which lies on the (*) Absheron peninsula. This country's tallest mountain, Mount Bazardüzü [baz-ar-doo-joo], is located on the border between it and Dagestan. The disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh is surrounded by the territory of this country. For 10 points, name this country to the east of Georgia and Armenia whose capital, Baku, is on the Caspian Sea.

One vein that drains this organ is compressed between the aorta and mesenteric artery in Nutcracker syndrome. This organ's function can be assessed by measuring serum creatinine levels. In response to hypoxic conditions, this organ stimulates the production of red blood cells by releasing erythropoietin. Countercurrent multiplication maintains a strong osmotic gradient in this organ. The pituitary gland releases (*) vasopressin to signal the reabsorption of water into this organ. In this organ, renal corpuscles consist of a glomerulus attached to a Bowman's capsule, which are part of this organ's functional unit, the nephron. For 10 points, name this organ that filters blood and creates urine

One composer who played this instrument in Paul Whiteman's orchestra composed a suite with a final "Cloudburst" movement that was used as the score to the Disney film Grand Canyon. A "Charleston rhythm" is featured in the first movement of a Concerto in F for this instrument. Ferde Grofe played this instrument. A performer of this instrument wrote an opera in which Remus saves the title character from being thrown into a (*) wasp's nest. A piece for this instrument was named after a club in Sedalia, Missouri. A jazz band accompanies this instrument in a piece that begins with a clarinet glissando, George Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue.  For 10 points, The Entertainer and Maple Leaf Rag were written by Scott Joplin for what keyboard instrument?
tossups.answer: pianoforte [the powermark clue refers to Treemonisha, by Scott Joplin]
tossups.answer_formatted: pianoforte [the powermark clue refers to Treemonisha, by Scott Joplin]

tossups.question: A politician with this surname claimed that "Ulster is becoming Britain's Vietnam." Another politician with this surname and his wife Carolyn Bessette died in a small plane he was flying near Martha's Vineyard. A politician with this surname, who gained the nickname the Lion of the Senate, was accused of killing the speechwriter Mary Jo Kopechne in the (*) Chappaquiddick incident. Another politician with this surname gave a speech on the flatbed of a truck following Martin Luther King, Jr.'s assassination during a presidential primary campaign against Hubert Humphrey. Sirhan Sirhan assassinated that politician with this surname. For 10 points, give this surname of a Massachusetts political family whose members included Ted, Robert, and the U.S. president John.
tossups.answer: Kennedy [accept Edward Kennedy or Ted Kennedy or Robert Kennedy or Bobby Kennedy or John F. Kennedy Jr.]
tossups.answer_formatted: Kennedy [accept Edward Kennedy or Ted Kennedy or Robert Kennedy or Bobby Kennedy or John F. Kennedy Jr.]

tossups.question: After being confronted by one character during a parade, this character rebuffs "He is a dreamer. Let us leave him. Pass." In a speech about this character, another person exclaims "O Judgement! Thou art fled to brutish beasts" before saying that his "heart is in the coffin" with this character. In one speech, a statesman recounts how this character was presented with "a kingly crown, Which he did thrice refuse"; that speech, which is intended to (*) bury [this character], not to praise him," begins, "Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears." This character ignores the warnings of Calpurnia and a soothsayer who says to "Beware the Ides of March." For 10 points, name this title character of a Shakespeare play who exclaims "Et tu, Brute" before being stabbed.

bonuses.leadin: Let's explore the chaos that Fenrir caused at Ragnarok. For 10 points each:
parts: This object turns black after Surtr defeats Freyr at Ragnarok. According to one story, Fenrir will devour this object at Ragnarok.
This Norse god of Vengeance avenges his father's death by killing Fenrir using his extremely thick shoe to tear apart its jaw.
This father of Vidar is eaten by Fenrir at Ragnarok. This "All-father" of the Aesir sacrificed one of his eyes to Mimir's Well to gain the world's knowledge.
answers: Odin [accept Wotan or Wuotan or Wodan or Woden]

bonuses.leadin: Cells that produce this compound are found in the cell groups A8 to A14. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this compound that is received by the islands of Calleja [cai-ay-ha] from the ventral tegmental area. The synthesis of this compound begins with the hydroxylation of tyrosine.
Dopamine is an example of one of these compounds in the brain. Other catecholamines, such as epinephrine, are examples of these compounds that transmit signals between neurons.

Loss of dopamine-producing cells in the substantia nigra causes this disease characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein inclusions. Symptoms of this disease include loss of muscle control and tremors.

bonuses.leadin: In one poem, this author wrote about an object that was "An artificial wilderness / And a sky like lead." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poet who described an object depicting a "weed-choked field" in the "Shield of Achilles." He also wrote a poem about the start of World War II titled "September 1, 1939."
Auden described this poet of "The Stolen Child" as an "Irish vessel" who has been "scattered among a hundred cities" after his death in a poem titled "In Memory of" this author.

Auden described "Whispering neighbors left and right" in a poem titled for this time period's "song." Another poem about this time period by John Keats calls it a "season of mists and mellow fruitfulness"

bonuses.leadin: A propaganda poster for this organization depicts Western star Gary Cooper and is titled "High Noon, June 4, 1989." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this trade union founded at the Lenin shipyards. This organization's members were elected to the "Contract Sejm" in the June 4, 1989 elections, removing its country's Soviet-backed government.
Solidarity was a political party in this country. Lech Walesa led protests against this country's corrupt, Warsaw-based government.

A sister movement to Solidarity that vandalized buildings with pictures of dwarves was known as the "this adjective Alternative." This adjective describes a revolution in Ukraine that erupted after Leonid Kuchma kidnapped journalist Georgiy Gongadze during the 2004 elections.
answers: Orange [accept Orange Alternative or Orange Revolution]

bonuses.leadin: In the finale of Beethoven's symphony of this number, the orchestra plays a fortissimo C-sharp before modulating from the tonic of F major to F-sharp minor. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this number. Mahler's symphony of this number contains a setting of the "Veni Creator Spiritus" hymn in its first section.

Beethoven's biographer Anton Schindler falsely claimed that the second movement of the Eighth Symphony was based on the ticking of this device. Johann Maelzel invented this musical device to keep tempo.

The Eighth Symphony was mostly ignored during Beethoven's lifetime, partly because its premiere was overshadowed by this patriotic overture. This overture, which celebrated the British victory at the Battle of Vitoria, was originally written for Maelzel's panharmonicon.

bonuses.leadin: Remember the Alamo! And some other stuff too. For 10 points each:
parts: Remember this 1836 massacre where James Fannin's retreating troops were massacred by Mexican forces. Along with "Remember the Alamo," participants in the Texas Revolution urged comrades to "Remember" this massacre.
Remember this notoriously racist president of Texas, who led the fledgling republic to financial insolvency after issuing the worthless "Redback" currency.
Remember this general who was succeeded by Mirabeau Lamar as president of the Republic of Texas. This first president of the Republic of Texas names Texas' largest city.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the Argentine composer Alberto Ginastera. For 10 points each:
parts: One of Ginastera's most famous works is based on a narrative poem by Estanislao del Campo, in which a gaucho attends a performance of this opera. In this opera, one character repeats the lines "Ah, I laugh to see myself / so beautiful in this mirror" in the aria "Ah, je ris de me voir."
Ginastera drew upon gaucho culture to write a work in this genre called Estancia, much like Aaron Copland drew from cowboy culture to write works in this form like Rodeo! and Appalachian Spring.

Ginastera heavily used a "chord" named for this instrument in his Opus 47, a concerto dedicated to Carlos Barbosa Lima, a virtuoso of this instrument. This instrument was also played by Andres Segovia.
answers: Faust [it's by Charles Gounod - the aria might be better known as the "Jewel Song"]
answers_formatted: Faust [it's by Charles Gounod - the aria might be better known as the "Jewel Song"]

bonuses.leadin: This body of water lies between New Brunswick and Nova Scotia. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this bay whose Hopewell Rocks are partially submerged during the day because of its extreme tidal range.
Because of its high tides, the Bay of Fundy contains one of these phenomena. In these phenomena, strong tides form a wave that goes upstream on a river.
The Bay of Fundy is generally considered an arm of a gulf named for this state. This Northeastern state's capital is Augusta.

bonuses.leadin: In the subplot of this play, Kitely becomes afraid that his wife is cheating on him with men brought home by his brother-in-law, Wellbred. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play which climaxes when the judge Clement exposes all of the characters as based in an obsession.
Every Man in His Humor was written by this playwright, who also wrote a play about Subtle and Face conning others in The Alchemist.
This most famous play by Ben Jonson sees the title character and his servant Mosca try to con Corbaccio, Corvino, and Voltore into giving them gifts by feigning illness and later death

bonuses.leadin: Lars Onsager's improvement to a theory partially named after this man states that all particles in a given solution undergo Brownian motion. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this scientist who, along with Erich Hückel, names a theory that predicts the non-ideal behavior of electrolytes in solution. This scientist also developed a model where specific heat was proportional to temperature cubed.
Onsager also provided a two-dimensional solution to a model that represents this phenomenon as a set of discrete spins in a lattice. The "anti-" form of this property disappears above the Neel point

Onsager's work with Debye and Hückel in Switzerland centered around electrolytes, which create these species when placed in solution. These species are atoms or molecules that have a non-zero net charge.
answers: Peter Debye [accept Debye-Hückel theory or Debye-Hückel equation or Debye model]
ferromagnetism [prompt on magnetism] (the model is the Ising model)
answers_formatted: Peter Debye [accept Debye-Hückel theory or Debye-Hückel equation or Debye model]
metadata: the model is the Ising model

bonuses.leadin: This runner has stated that she smoked marijuana in order to cope with the recent death of her mother. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American female runner. This runner was recently suspended from competing at the Olympics because of a positive test for THC.
Richardson ran in college for a school in this state before turning professional. That school named for this state is located in its city of Baton Rouge.
Sha'carri Richardson was sponsored by this brand for the US Olympic Trials. This company, which is headquartered in Beaverton, was founded by Bill Bowerman and Phil Knight.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about problems with physics models. For 10 points each:
parts: Currently, the standard model does not account for this force. This force's namesake constant is denoted big G and appears in Newton's inverse square law for this attractive force.

The Sakharov conditions describe how these particles and their antimatter counterparts can be produced at different rates after the Big Bang in their namesake "-genesis." This class of particles consist of an odd number of quarks and includes protons and neutrons.
This other theory is missing some baryons. This theory, known as the "standard model of cosmology,"  parameterizes the universe in terms of matter and its two title components.
answers: lambda-CDM model [or Lambda cold dark matter model]

bonuses.leadin: After failing to protect a goat, the main character of this novel is locked in a shed with its corpse for 10 days. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Fuka-Eri novel that describes how the "Little People" emerged from the carcass of that goat and forced her to construct the title object.
Tengo edits the manuscript of Air Chrysalis in this novel. At the end of this novel, Tengo and Aomame stare up at a sky with two moons.
This author wrote 1Q84, alongside novels such as Kafka on the Shore and Norwegian Wood.

bonuses.leadin: One leader of this country urged readers to "Seek ye first the political kingdom" in his tract "Africa Must Unite." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country formerly known as the Gold Coast. While a member of the "Big Six," one leader of this country was arrested for leading riots in this country's capital of Accra.
This leader's Convention People's Party usurped Charles Arden-Clarke, allowing this leader to become the first postcolonial president of Ghana.

After being overthrown by the National Liberation Council, this politician granted Nkrumah refuge in his country. This first Premier of the People's Republic of China created the "Four Modernizations" economic policy.

bonuses.leadin: Mullah Nasruddin is an anecdotal figure found in many folktales throughout the world. Answer the following about him, for 10 points each:
parts: Nasruddin is sometimes named for having performed this action. Umrah is a variant of this action that can be done at any time in the year.

In one anecdote, Nasruddin falls asleep with his feet pointing towards this structure, which is circled in the hajj. Muslims pray in the direction of this building in Mecca, the holiest site in Islam.

In many anecdotes about Nasruddin, he is accompanied by one of these animals. Zechariah prophesied that the Messiah would be accompanied by both one of these animals and its young at the same time, in many translations.

bonuses.leadin: This artist's cartoonish alter ego is a mouse-like figure called MR. DOB. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this "Superflat" contemporary artist who painted scarring teddy bears on Kanye West's album Graduation and created prints of Jellyfish Eyes for his collaboration with Louis Vuitton.
Murakami is from this country, which is also home to Yayoi Kusama, a fellow contemporary artist.

Kusama often incorporated these designs into her artworks, including one in which black versions of these things are painted over yellow pumpkins. Another one of her works involve obliterating a white room with these objects.

bonuses.leadin: A member of this family hires a detective to investigate a bookseller named Arthur Geiger who is trying to blackmail his daughter Carmen. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this family, another member of which kills Rusty Regan in The Big Sleep.
This author included Philip Marlowe in his novel The Big Sleep and declared "the average detective story is no worse than the average novel" in his essay "The Simple Art of Murder."
The Big Sleep is set in this city. In The Day of the Locust, Tod Hackett moves to this California city's neighborhood of Hollywood.

bonuses.leadin: One experiment by this psychologist involved people shadowing speech but seeming to be talking for themselves to another person. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this psychologist. He also led an experiment in which people from the Midwest tried to forward packages to Boston to test our degree of social interconnectedness.
Milgram laid the framework for these people in psychological experiments, who speak the words of another person that are conveyed to them by a radio transmitter.
Cyranoids have been used to study the way that adults speak to these people. Jean Piaget concluded that these people go through four stages of cognitive development before adulthood.
answers: children [accept babies or infants; accept 12-year olds]

bonuses.leadin: As the number of degrees of freedom approaches infinity, the Student's t-distribution approaches this distribution. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this distribution often referred to as a bell curve. Z-tests are only applicable for distributions that are approximately this distribution.
As the number of samples increases, any sampling distribution becomes approximately normal according to this theorem. This theorem applies when the sample size is greater than 30.
For a normal distribution, this value is 3. This quantity indicates the tendency of a distribution to produce outlier values and measures its "tailedness."

bonuses.leadin: This ruler died after a Laconic woman dropped a tile on his head during a Siege of Argos. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ruler who allegedly exclaimed "One more victory and we are undone!" after a victory at the Battle of Asculum. The term for a costly victory is named after this ruler.
Pyrrhus briefly co-ruled this kingdom with Demetrius I Poliorcetes. Demetrius's father was a one-eyed ruler of this kingdom and fought in the Wars of the Diadochi.
Pyrrhus married the daughter of Ptolemy I Soter, who ruled over a region centered on this river. This river ran through the heart of Egypt.
